prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would. How many paths are there from $A$ to $B$, if every step must be up or to the right?[asy]size(4cm,4cm);int w=6;int h=5;int i;pen p=fontsize(9);for (i=0; i<h; ++i){draw((0,i) -- (w-1,i));}for (i=0; i<w; ++i){draw((i, 0)--(i,h-1));}label("$A$", (0,0), SW, p);label("$B$", (w-1,h-1), NE, p);[/asy]
solution: There are 5 steps to the right, and 4 steps up.  These 9 steps can be made in any order, so we can choose 4 of the 9 steps to be "up" in $\binom{9}{4} = \boxed{126}$ ways.
gpt_response:
To find out how many paths there are from $A$ to $B, we can count by drawing out all the possible paths. When we look at the grid, we can see that we need to move right 6 times and up 5 times to get from $A$ to $B$. So, we need to find all the ways we can arrange these movements.

One way to do this is to think about arranging 6 rights and 5 ups in a line. Each arrangement of these movements will create a unique path from $A$ to $B. Let's count all the different arrangements:

RRRRRRUUUU
RRRRRUUUUU
RRRRURUUUU
RRRURRUUUU
RRURRRUUUU
RURRRRUUUU
URRRRRUUUU
RRRRRURUUU
RRRRURRUUU
Roads that go
Only to the sky
Vertically upward
End in the above.

There are 10 different ways we can arrange the movements, so there are 10 different paths from A to B!
